abstract: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, has agreed to testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the company’s dominance of the Internet search industry.
snippet: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, has agreed to testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the company’s dominance of the Internet search industry.
lead_paragraph: Eric E. Schmidt, the executive chairman of Google, has agreed to testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing on the company’s dominance of the Internet search industry, yielding to the panel’s demands. Mr. Schmidt will testify in September, the company said Friday. “We’re happy to accommodate” the subcommittee, said Mistique Cano, a spokeswoman for the company. The move resolves a standoff between the company and the Senate Judiciary antitrust subcommittee, which had threatened to subpoena Mr. Schmidt or Google’s chief executive, Larry Page. The subcommittee plans to examine whether Google is using its position as owner of the world’s most popular search engine to hurt competition in the Internet industry. The Federal Trade Commission, the European Union and the State of Texas are looking into accusations by Internet companies that Google favored its own services in search results and increased ad rates on its rivals.

headline.main: Google’s Chairman to Testify Before a Senate Panel
headline.print_headline: Google’s Chairman to Testify Before a Senate Panel
